Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Geotechnical Fundamentals in the Face of New Challenges, Arlington, VA, January, 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This workshop will be held at the National Science Foundation in Arlington, Virginia on January 25-27, 2016. It will focus on fundamental principles that underlie current and anticipated developments in geotechnical engineering. It will provide an open forum for experts to meet and discuss common fundamental research themes that underline geotechnical engineering. This workshop will be the first one to cut-across different fundamental research themes. The workshop will: (1) establish a clear milestone in fundamental research that sustains the geotechnical engineering field, (2) capture current developments and promote brainstorming for research visions, (3) identify gaps and needs, as well as applications that hold the greatest potential, and (4) explore approaches for enhancing the teaching of fundamental principles in geotechnical engineering.

Fundamental principles in physics, chemistry, biology, and thermodynamics provide the essential knowledge needed to address emerging challenges and to advance new engineering possibilities in the broad field of geotechnology. These range from opportunities related to bio-mediated ground modification, to unanticipated emergent phenomena in subsurface energy exploration and storage. The complex inter-dependences and interactions among hydrological, chemical, thermal, biological, and mechanical processes in natural settings and engineered geo-systems, from the pore-grain scale to the macro-engineering scale, challenge the existing understanding, motivate current research, and suggest the societal need for new content in research and educational programs in geotechnology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A two-and-a-half-day National Science Foundation (NSF) sponsored workshop entitled "Geotechnical Fundamentals in the Face of New World Challenges" was held in July 2016 at the headquarters of NSF in Arlington, VA. The workshop focused on fundamental principles that underlie current and anticipated developments in geotechnical and geo-environmental engineering, with an emphasis on how the geotechnical research community can contribute to the real-world challenges facing humanity today. Forty researchers attended the workshop, representing a range of technical backgrounds, diversity, and career stages. Participants from oversea were able to provide an international perspective.

The workshop opened with presentations and a discussion on the current state of fundamental geotechnical research and implications for societal “grand” challenges, as well as the future of geotechnical engineering. The role that fundamental understanding of geo-material behavior has played, and will continue to play, in technical advances was emphasized. Areas where fundamental work is still needed to address knowledge gaps. Examples included: a potential need to re-visit, or update, existing soil classification systems; the need for new measurement and data-driven approaches in geotechnical engineering, the ongoing challenges of modeling multi-scale problems – especially in the presence of heterogeneous material properties -  and knowledge gaps in unsaturated soil behavior. “Grand” challenge areas that the geotechnical community is positioned to lead in addressing were also highlighted: these included developments of a low carbon economy, management of global groundwater resources and enhancements of urban sustainability and resilience. 

During Day two of the workshop, participants explored fundamentals and challenges in the areas of bio-mediated geo-processes, geo-chemistry, unsaturated soils, and thermal energy and foundations. One common theme that emerged was the problem of up-scaling – how to move promising techniques for soil modification and improvement from the laboratory to the field, for example. It was noted that, unlike material modification methods in many other fields, geotechnical applications often require the treatment of large volumes of material at low cost. Challenge areas identified under this umbrella included: understanding the distribution and level of treatment needed for different techniques; methods for verifying the distribution of treated soil over large areas, and monitoring and soil characterization methods for different spatial scales (nano-to-macro) and different time scales (short-to-long terms). Another common theme that emerged was the need for improved understanding of how coupled processes, including bio-geo-chemical-, multi-phase fluid- and thermal-processes, influence geo-material behavior. It was noted that the geotechnical field can be very self-contained as a discipline, and that increased collaboration with other researchers investigating materials behavior might expand perspectives on available approaches for materials testing, monitoring and characterization, as well as potentially applicable multi-scale modeling and up-scaling techniques.

During Day three of the workshop, participants explored the emerging challenges of rock mechanics, multi-physics and mechanics, and coupled phenomena.  Again, challenges with multi-scale characterization of geo-materials, linking behaviors across scales and dealing with coupled processes emerged as common themes. In addition, the complexity of dealing with phase transformations and energies associated was raised. For example, during freeze-thaw cycles in soils, pore fluids will transform from a solid to a liquid phase and vice-versa. Understanding and accounting for, how these transformations impact geo-material behavior in environmental processes, energy foundations, and geohazards remain fundamentally challenging.  Questions about how to best integrate soil and rock mechanics, in both research and education, also arose as part of Day three discussions.

In summary discussions of the workshop, several other common themes emerged as potentially unifying across all topics covered. One was the need to link soil classification systems to new measurement techniques to geo-material behaviors of existing or emerging interest. Another was the idea of advancing geo-community models, benchmarking techniques and data sets for certain classes of geotechnical problems. Yet another involved the mapping of geotechnical expertise to grand challenges identified by the National Academy of Engineering and others, and identifying areas where the geotechnical engineers and researchers could lead in assembling interdisciplinary expertise to address certain challenges.

Further information on the workshop, including the workshop program, workshop presentations and white papers, and attendees, can be found at the workshop website: http://www.nsfgeoworkshop2016.com/home.html. Contact information for the workshop organizers is also provided, and the organizers welcome any feedback. A final workshop report will be publically available via the workshop website by the end of 2018.
